title: As We Leave #31: Change is the only constant, Embrace it, don‚Äôt differentiate it ;)
content: Disclaimer: Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur, is the exclusive owner of the information on this website. No part of this content may be duplicated, paraphrased, or interpreted in any other way without written consent from Vox Populi. If you want to reproduce any of the content on this page, please contact our chief editors directly or reach out to us by email atvoxpopuli@iitk.ac.in.

‚ÄòWhat does this place truly offer? Academia? Placements? Endless walls we call hostels? Or is it something deeper, learnings, late night chaos, friendships that felt like family, memories etched in corridors, and a quiet confidence that built over time?
It‚Äôs all about how we perceive, how we mould ourselves, and how we ‚Äúchange‚Äù ‚Äô

In this 31st edition ofAs We Leave, Vishal Himmatsinghka, a graduating Y21 student from Electrical engineering department shares what these 4 years, this college gave, took, and ultimately made of him. To know the breakdowns, the breakthroughs, and versions, have a read.

Disclaimer:- The views presented below are the author‚Äôs own and are not in any manner representative of the views of Vox Populi as a body or IIT Kanpur in general. This is an informal account of the author‚Äôs experiences at IITK.

So, it‚Äôs that time, the AWL time. Time for class of 2025 to leave, time for me to leave. Before I start throwing random thoughts tangled with some facts and advices, a little disclaimer that writing this was never easy. Sometimes, it‚Äôs too short, sometimes, out of words and all the time emotional to pen down this journey of 4 years in a single blog. So this is going to be about me who came here and the one who‚Äôs leaving. It‚Äôs going to be a long story short where a guy with a lot of ambition, immaturity and yes ‚Äòenthu‚Äô survives between the brightest minds of the country.

So Hiii, I am Vishal, first I will introduce you to the Vishal who came here, yes we both aren‚Äôt same. So when He came here in the 2nd sem, ugh he was a bit unlucky and our college actually started in the 2nd sem when we got the chance to get back to campus (Post covid batch). He was from a small city Dumka somehow managed to crack JEE and get admission here at EE. Yes he was overwhelmed and scared. Scared because it was the first time he was stepping out of home, was not sure what he likes, hobbies??, insecurities? Many, academic bts (yes already had), surrounded by doubts that if he could make it. On top of all that, due to personal reasons he came here late, missed the orientation, which is counted as the stepping stone to make friends, know people, get acquainted with places on campus (Ig that‚Äôs why I still do not know places on campus :/) Knowing him, it must be quite obvious that he didn‚Äôt have many online friends either. Though he knew that it was a blank slate and a lot is ahead and he just wanted to make this count, wanted to make everyone proud.

There is so much to pen down but Ik I am out of time and words (Today is deadline and it‚Äôs what IITK taught me). So will add some key events which help you understand how he became me (Ugh It‚Äôs already getting complicated. Also an advice to get used to acronyms, I use many :P).

Ofc a memorable one for everyone. Mine was a bit different from the batch, 16th April 2022. Already missed an Antrangini too (yes woh Ritviz wali). Wandered in the scorching heat to get my ID card trying hard to remember the paths (Just to mention, I lost them both) looking around the overwhelming campus, the flora, the roads, bought a cycle too (close to me) and then I entered a lecture hall L19 for the first time, the biggest I had seen ever 400+ students sitting in a set-up of a competition, you wanna know which one? Guesstimate by FAC. Will make more sense as the story proceeds. It all felt like a dream which that lost kid wanted to live at fullest. Meanwhile I met my wing, my roommate (talked with him for the first time, not a surprise). I remember the next day having a quiz later on, of course MTH102 (Hated by all defeated by none). I just slept at 11PM, which was very normal for me, then I saw my roommate Praneat started studying and then I woke up at 6AM. He was still there on the desk and I realized what an all nighter is üôÇ Quite shocked trying to sink in how it works, it was kinda the first hit for me.

Now this was how it started for me. The rest of this semester went into getting used to how things work here, followed by a disciplined life (For me it‚Äôs eating mess food daily and attending all the classes). And then clubs (Gymkhana wale :)) came into picture, in which I was involved the least earlier. Wanted to get in one as I thought it was important from ‚ÄòPOR‚Äô POV. Which laid the foundation of the next chapter.

It wasn‚Äôt a great start tbh, had an operation dealing with health issues (dropped to almost 40 Kgs, yes real). But but, that kid wasn‚Äôt going to give up this early. Collected the will and tried getting into places he likes (which was itself uncertain). Found my first club, Chess club, got into it for creativity but it helped me relieve my passion for chess once again. Now comes SnT clubs, I definitely wanted to get into one. PClub tasks came and seemed out of league (Luckily) and had some past with finance so I tried to be in FAC which later became more than just a club to me. I am very grateful to my seniors (if you are reading this) for believing in me at that time, even though I wasn‚Äôt able to do the same. Worked hard as a secy, as finally I got something I like, a place I feel I belonged to and later on continued to become the Coordinator of the same club I attended the first event of. I got a chance to represent IITK in 2 Inter-IIT tech meets, and it brought me to the new definition of competition, teamwork and trust. The fight the GradCap team and Zelta team made, the sleepless nights had awakened something in me, a sense of purpose, the will to keep going, giving best and never stopping. It was my honor and definitely the highlight of the journey in between. Since we are talking about tough times, there comes the internship season at the end of 2nd year, dw won‚Äôt take much time you can find my journey here ‚Äìhttps://medium.com/@ug_anc/the-more-you-know-1-sde-8e04336dc07a(thank you AnC for capturing this). And I feel third year is the best as it challenges the most, being coordinator helped me to think like a leader, take upfront responsibilities and become accountable for others as well. I bonded with my team and luckily accepted by all. Someone told me I have this unique power to make people like me, I felt it here, it felt like a family where they looked up to me and it always kept me going. The journey in between wasn‚Äôt just about clubs, was much more than that, I belonged from hall 2 (I LOVE MY HALL), have special place for it where I became part of TEAM CANTEEN, a friend group that formed with the love of canteen food (Or the hate of mess) but stayed for much more than that (in and beyond). Being part of takneek, fests, elections, the grind, the unsaid walks, cycling and roaming around the campus (and ending up getting lost :P) are all core memories of this chapter as I move ahead with the final lap.

And just like that the senior year started. Going back to college after an internship is never the same. An entire batch is gone, Some people close to you are not there anymore. This time when we have seen how the world actually works, we value campus life much more. Started on a rough path by losing two of my best friends to a different hall (H9, but actually never lost them and ended up even closer). And the stress of placements looms and odd sem being an odd sem brought many challenges.¬† Everyone nervously waited for the PPO results, so did I. But but but, I got lucky, before I started making a resume I got the offer, a dream got fulfilled. Was it easy onwards? Never. There was an emptiness, now there was no place I had to go. Days were spent mostly in the room, it was the time I spent with myself, learnt what I like, worked on my hobbies. Started appreciating nature. A peacock in the morning was making my day beautiful. It was a strange time, which left a huge impact on me. Meanwhile, did the placement season end here? No. Winter was coming, not me but my close ones were there, some trying, some helpless and I wanted to be there, it‚Äôs not even a choice. This was the highlight of the sem giving tests all day in G113 followed by attending the last Antrangini (gotta see Ritviz this time). It was a special one, like a break between the chaos until it turned into chaos itself. Then December happened, my people got placed and the final lap (the fun part) started. Time to finish the unplanned trips, Remember completing four trips in this duration, was finally able to decide I am a beach person over a mountain, winters over summers and my gallery was filled with the endless memories. Last semester is just bittersweet, it‚Äôs the time you want to stop, meet as many as you can and create as many memories. I wandered around to discover some new places in my last days at campus, visited some unvisited rooftops and also the places that I associated with. Parties all around‚Ä¶ Discovered another side of me. (Being a senior you have to give many, so be prepared :)) This time you care less about things once most important for you (yes talking about acads). This final lap helped me find myself.

Finally, let‚Äôs meet up now. Hiii, I am Vishal and I find myself lucky to spend most of the time in college on this beautiful campus. Now in a big city, Bangalore somehow managed to crack a decent job. Yes, now I am confident because of the love and experiences I got here. Hobbies?? Many ‚Äì You can find me scratching my pen on a diary trying to pen down a thought, a poem or a story. Or maybe doing some sort of digital art. And yes sometimes sliding over the candlesticks (I meant markets, weird hobbies ik). Can talk about N series and anime, started reading books and ofc chess, I love it. Though still clumsy and messy, lost in directions and yes some things never change, maybe for the good. On top of all that, I participated in all the final year rituals, including batch photoshoots, or dance extravaganza, writing emo wale testimonials, or scribbling day, or writing letter to 10 years future me (talking with future and past, yes Dark is going on:)) and finally farewells, the parties and writing this AWL. This Vishal didn‚Äôt miss any of them. And now knowing me, it must be quite obvious that I met many amazing people on this journey. The blank slate is filled with memories of lifetime, learnings to stay forever and people to stay close. And yes, the first year me, made everyone proud from where he is, leaving with gratitude!
So thus I learnt, ‚ÄúChange is the only constant. Embrace it, don‚Äôt differentiate it‚Äù (else it will be zero) üòâ
The family I made here. Ones who loved me unconditionally and were there for me. This one is going to stay. No words can describe its importance. ALWAYS TOGETHER.
The smallest wing that made me feel included. Always felt a special bond, will remember the parties, fun and trips. Thank y‚Äôall.
FAC:My club, that helped me grow the most.
The best people I met, the place that gave me confidence. A part of me will always be there and a part of FAC with me. V0DK@S forever.
That random group with not so random yaari. Most comfortable people to joke with,sit with, and share with. Matlabi aise ho toh matlabi duniya hi sahi hai!
Ones very close to me. Always respectful and supportive, fun to party with. Motivated me to work harder. Will miss them a lot and wish them all the success. Thanks for your not so legal testimonials!
Thank you for getting here, believing in yourself and never giving up. Now it‚Äôs my turn to make you proud.
As he leave, he leaves with pride,High on emotions, nothing to hide.A lot to carry, a lot in sight,He is leaving, but something of him will live inside.

When he came, was like a broken vase,Tough to find pieces, touching gives scars.He felt alone, in a sea of crowd,Always thinking what this missing all about.He was scared, inside his room,Hesitant to step out like there is some goon.

But his will was stronger, he wanted to fight,He wanted to live, even its wrong or right.He got some people, some purpose to chase,Seems he is now getting use to this maze.But ups and downs always came his way,Again he broke, again he stayed.

He was getting good, the prison is home,Not leaving this is the only thing he hope.Solving the puzzle, he found himself,In a place where he just wanted to escape.The new him loves whatever comes by,Applauding whatever the old one went by.

Though time to part had drawn in near,The broken pieces of vase reappeared.He wanted to live all once again, but someone said it right,Good things last like that one magical night.He will miss the streets, the sky the trees around,Like they helped to get him found.

As he leaves, he leaves a lot behind,Taking things all in his mind.He will miss his friends, his people around,Ahh he is crying while writing this down.But yes we know, now he is strongSo when he leave he will leave with a smile,And when he returns, wave ‚ÄúHiii‚Äù from a mile!

Thanks to the reader if you stick it till here. I hope you can relate or learn something from my story (Everyone has their own, create yours). Ever need BTS of any chapter just ping I am here ‚Äì @_.vishal_03._ and professionally I am here ‚Äì https://www.linkedin.com/in/vishal-himmatsinghka-a82831240
Thanks to Vox for giving me this opportunity of pouring my thoughts for this last time and my CGM Suhani for the patience.
Lastly, thanks to my family, friends for being there for me in this journey and all along.

title: As We Leave #30: In Pursuit of Popularity
content: Disclaimer: Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur, is the exclusive owner of the information on this website. No part of this content may be duplicated, paraphrased, or interpreted in any other way without written consent from Vox Populi. In this 30th edition of As We Leave, Dwija Kakkad, a Y21 from the Department of Mathematics pens a story not of milestones, but of moments‚Äîof growing up, faltering, recalibrating, and learning to simply be. What began as a pursuit of ‚Äúcool‚Äù slowly gave way to quiet confidence, built on reflection.

Disclaimer:- The views presented below are the author‚Äôs own and are not in any manner representative of the views of Vox Populi as a body or IIT Kanpur in general. This is an informal account of the author‚Äôs experiences at IITK.

I always write methodically, professionally, afraid to let my feelings show. In this AWL, I will try to pen down my thoughts as they come, unfiltered. I have been reading all the AWLs Vox released since my first year, and the AWLs I enjoyed reading the most were the ones which offered a window into the writer‚Äôs mind, the ones which told the story of a person, of their campus experience. I intend to write a similar AWL.A story of my three and a half years here, consisting of anecdotes, some unsolicited advice, and more importantly, my emotions.I do not remember my years here in a linear fashion; some instances stand out more than others. If I sit back and think about what I remember‚Äì it‚Äôs random things‚Äì getting locked on the OAT rooftop with two other idiots yelling ‚Äòghost, ghost!,¬† listening to Ed Sheeran‚Äôs Subtract album on loop in KD during the intern-prep summer, late night ice-cream at Doaa canteen in study ‚Äòbreaks‚Äô, getting ready with the wing during fests, endless yap sessions at CCD. I am also more inclined to remember the highs than the lows. Perhaps that‚Äôs why my heart is full with the memories I made in my last semester here.

I have prided myself in being someone fairly emotionally detached from places and things. Unlike my friends, I didn‚Äôt feel ‚Äòsenti‚Äô or nostalgic during the last fest, or farewell, or the batch shoots, or even on the last day of classes. I felt a little guilty, too, for not feeling like I will miss this place or the people. I now realise that I was in denial. I don‚Äôt believe that this is the end. Every time an event occurs, my mind finds solace in the fact that at least we have that next thing planned. After attending the last ‚Äúthing‚Äù, sitting at the airport waiting to board the flight back home, I have nothing to look forward to. And that‚Äôs when it hits, the sentimentality, the nostalgia, the feeling of leaving a piece of yourself behind in a place, and taking a piece of everyone you loved back with you.

Recency bias plays a big role in me feeling so fondly towards this place, as I can confidently say that my 8th semester here was probably the best four months of my life. My journey here was far from linear, with me experiencing a myriad of emotions. I had started off as an ignorant kid, determined to leave her nerd self behind, and become ‚Äòcool‚Äô. I blatantly ignored academics in the online semester, I didn‚Äôt even have a benchmark on what a good CPI was. I remember asking a friend during the first ESC101 class if ‚Äòhard code‚Äô meant using ‚Äòharder‚Äô code for a simple task :). After coming to campus, I started caring a lot more about having the best college experience ever. I was determined to make a bunch of friends ‚Äòfor life‚Äô, determined to balance studying and making memories (they are not mutually exclusive, I realised much later). I even bought into the mindset of a few seniors I interacted with initially: ‚Äúacads toh hota rehta hai, make sure you do something worthwhile in your time here‚Äù. As a result, I stepped a little too much out of my comfort zone and allowed people to come much closer to me than I was comfortable with. I blindly followed the ‚Äòin‚Äô things to do: study all night the day before exams, join all the clubs you can, don‚Äôt attend classes. This bit me in the back (quite heavily, I must add). By the end of my third semester, I had dug myself into a deep academic hole, I felt suffocated in my friendships, and as a result withdrew fully, I stopped working for all the clubs I had joined. One great decision I made, however, was to apply to be a student guide. The 9 days of orientation were the highlight of that semester. The winter break after the third semester was spent doing almost nothing at home; I had even given up hope on preparing for the upcoming internship season.

I remember less the consequent semesters. Determined to do well in courses, I became antisocial, interacting with very few people, and started attending all classes. A ‚ÄúComplex Analysis‚Äù course I had to take in my fifth semester, a particular professor I started working with, a friend I made in my fourth semester, collectively helped me get out of this rut, although they probably don‚Äôt know it. I started enjoying math (just enough to get myself to study), actively started figuring out what I wanted to do in life, and started making new friends. I even went on my first college trip to Goa! I had always wanted to go for higher studies, but I had always restrained myself, thinking it almost impossible with my grades. However, I regained optimism after a few semesters of better performance, and somewhere in the 6th semester, I started toying with this idea again. Halfway into my corporate internship, I made the decision to apply to PhD programs in Statistics, and that summer was the busiest I had ever been‚Äìworking on projects, learning skills, preparing for the GRE, exploring Mumbai, and working just enough to justify my stipend :). My last semester was the zenith of my days here. I went on a trek with my equally unfit wingies, had a little too much fun in Techkriti üòâ , peaked academically, got into my dream program, and most importantly,I found a bunch of people, who I care about enough to make a serious effort to keep in my life.

Having experienced every possible emotion, from heartbreak to finding new love, losing friends and gaining new ones, seriously considering dropping out and joining a local college to making the decision to pursue (and hopefully complete) a PhD, trying to change my personality to fit in, to abandoning that and living the way I want and eventually finding people with whom hanging out felt effortless. Sleeping at 11 pm and faking headaches to avoid 12 am birthday celebrations to pulling all-nighters with friends, picking up multiple PoRs in a semester and abandoning them all to work on my abysmal grades. Religiously running home every break to planning multiple trips a semester (and running home on long weekends because some things don‚Äôt change), begging a prof relentlessly for three semesters to give me a project to end up publishing with her, not attending classes to pursuing professors even in office hours and back to not attending classes in my last semester, I feel like I‚Äôve had my fair share of college ‚Äòexperiences,‚Äô regardless of whether they conform to others‚Äô ideas of ‚Äòworthwhile‚Äô. Do I have regrets? Yes. I wish I had been smarter about managing my academics, I could have been more involved in the clubs I was a part of. I wish I had explored the campus more. I wish I had performed in at least one ME. But eh, you win some, you lose some. It‚Äôs all part of the story.

If anything, these years here have taught me that coolness is subjective, and running behind an arbitrary definition of ‚Äòcool‚Äô does no good at all. There is no set-in-stone bucket list of things one ‚Äúmust‚Äù do at IITK to truly live the ‚Äòcollege experience‚Äô. You make your own bucket list, and each is as good as the other. You write your own story. Advice from seniors and professors is highly personal and what works for one mostly doesn‚Äôt for another. All you can do is listen to this advice, make what you can of it, and try to do your best. Be comfortable with yourself. The confidence you get when you don‚Äôt have to pretend to be someone you‚Äôre not is worth it. One last piece of advice, or rather observation I will share, is that seeking help shamelessly has no loss and potentially infinite rewards. Go ask that professor to explain that proof, ask that topper to share their notes, ask seniors about what clubs to join, what internships to apply for, ask that friend to help you drape your saree. Not only will your effort be reduced, you might just find a bond for life.

I entered IITK an ignorant kid, desperate to leave her nerd self behind, and I am leaving IITK an ignorant adult embracing herself the way she is, and ready to make her fair share of mistakes in another country.
Written by: Dwija Kakkad
Edited by: Saurya Singh, Aaliyah Ahmed

title: As We Leave #29: My Pursuit of Happyness
content: Disclaimer: Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur, is the exclusive owner of the information on this website. No part of this content may be duplicated, paraphrased, or interpreted in any other way without written consent from Vox Populi. If you want to reproduce any of the content on this page, please contact our chief editors directly or reach out to us by email atvoxpopuli@iitk.ac.in.

In this 29th edition of As We Leave, Om Shrivastava, a Y21 from the Department of Electrical Engineeringunfurls our campus cut version of ‚ÄúThe Pursuit of Happyness‚Äù: disheartened JOSAA results to heart filled gratitude. From blank Zoom squares to midnight war rooms, from Tech-Meet golds to a council gavel that never cooled; Om‚Äôs story is a slow burn of doubt, grit, and self discovery. Between the all-nighters and an unintentional manifestation ‚Äì ‚Äúparty confession‚Äù.¬† This version of AWL carries the missed calls, side glances and whispered ‚Äúwhat if‚Äôs‚Äù that make the wins land harder. It doesn‚Äôt end with a placement, it ends with chasing a postcode called ‚Äúbelonging‚Äù, learning that closed doors do creak if you keep knocking.

From having doubted every move to crafting every bit of himself, ready to walk into theunknown: imperfect, but steady~this is a story of ‚Äúbecoming‚Äù. And maybe, just maybe, that‚Äôs what its all about?

Disclaimer:- The views presented below are the author‚Äôs own and are not in any manner representative of the views of Vox Populi as a body or IIT Kanpur in general. This is an informal account of the author‚Äôs experiences at IITK.

Before we dive into the whole saga, let me introduce myself. So hi to all the readers out there, I‚Äôm Om Shrivastava. Before writing this, I was in complete mayhem, where to begin, where to end, what all to include, and most importantly, how to conclude everything in a single extract with a perfect moral to it. C‚Äômon, life isn‚Äôt perfect, and neither am I, especially in the writing part, God forbid! So here‚Äôs my feeble attempt at bringing to you the journey of a boy, an introvert, so much so that he won‚Äôt leave his room for days, to a boy who wouldn‚Äôt even get the chance to come to his room for days. Throughout my journey, one thing I came to believe was ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.

The old me, who was rejoicing in a corner for getting IITKGP MnC in the first round, had no idea how his table would turn around in the 5th round with his seat upgradation to IITK EE. I didn‚Äôt have enough rank based on the past cutoff of EE here, how could it happen? Let‚Äôs just say it was all pre-destined, as I had only filled IITK EE above in choice, I was certain I won‚Äôt get it. But that time, I couldn‚Äôt regret it more. The academics of Kanpur, and on top of that, Electrical, the one thing that not only Facebook and Quora (c‚Äômon, it was really popular then) but my own physics solving capabilities refused the most. I couldn‚Äôt regret my life choice anymore than.

Fast-forwarding to the online semester. The fear of how I would sustain competition here, since now everyone around me is better in their own way, at least that‚Äôs what I thought. All the struggle of the past 2 years of JEE prep came up, all the work I did had gone to vain? My fears came to life when I got TA101 as one of the courses. As a person who can‚Äôt, for my own life, draw a single straight line, having to draw all 4 views of random objects, was nothing short of depression to me. My introvertedness was only adding to it, and with it being online sem, the only person to whom I could reach out for help was my elder brother, who would help me do my assignments. I was so much of an introvert that even during the online bulla sessions, I wouldn‚Äôt connect with anyone, switching off my cam & mic all the time, I didn‚Äôt even know any of my wingies‚Äô names (or what does wing mean), no contact was made, I was as solitary as you can imagine me to be. Somehow, I managed the online thing by simply doing nothing except ranting about my choice.

Then one very fine day, when we received mail about our offline return, it was nothing short of happiness for me, but there, in hindsight, was this introverted person with low self-esteem and confidence owing to his fear of disinterest in chosen major, whispering in his ear all the things that could go wrong. There I was on the IIT Kanpur campus, trying to make myself a little place in this huge suburb. We started with orientation, everything was fine until the bond and connect. My introversion took a toll on me, and the nervousness of communicating with such a huge group forced me back to my comfort zone. I made a health excuse and left the place, thus skipping even the following day of orientation.

Throughout the entire offline semester, I did what every fresher does, night out with your wingies, water fight with C6 (We were in B6), playing mafia, roaming across campus, and most importantly wing outings.

Let‚Äôs come to what I didn‚Äôt do? Freshers (I didn‚Äôt even know it existed, didn‚Äôt knew when it happened), Scavenger Hunt (just because, at least, all my known ones were just not interested, and I didn‚Äôt ask any other group to take me in).Though I was happy enough with the people I had by then in my life, all the late night talks, sharing things, pulling out pranks, Harlem shake with wingies, and most special, the day before the exam, looking back at pictures brings out all the nostalgia a man could have.

You know, how people say that change can be about only if a person finds something so touching that it forces them to change. Me? I would like to transfer his big baggage of credit to Chitresh, who once criticised me badly for staying in my room so often and sitting idly. His words were and I quote ‚ÄúSaale bas magta reh baith k,bahar kbhi niklega nhi,, kuch nhi hoga tera.‚Äù Harsh as those felt at that time, it certainly marked a turning point for me.

So with no involvement whatsoever, I first tried to go for those PoRs where prior involvement didn‚Äôt carry much weightage. So, AnC and PPOC were an easy bag-in, which did make me rethink how easy it is to get a PoR. Then, a chain reaction followed. Seeing everywhere apply at multiple places, I too applied for SPO and SnT, and guess what? Being a secretary was not as big of a deal as I thought it to be.

First time an introvert got out of his little box was certainly overwhelming. Though I still couldn‚Äôt overcome my fear of speaking publicly, I did use this opportunity to gain much more than experience, a network of all these seniors and batchmates. With cold, wispy winter air came the buzz of Inter IIT Tech Meet. Shivam Singhal, a close senior, introduced me to it and suggested I prepare in advance for selection, and man, did it take more than just preparation. After facing multiple rejections, it was the Team Humanoid and Robo club that came to the surface and got me selected into JLR Mid Prep PS. Those 15 days of bunking in Hall-12 Robo club room (our new home on campus) with a bunch of us inexperienced 2nd years were all worthwhile, with the happiness I felt after seeing my visible contribution in the PS. The memories I made, the bonding I developed with the best Y20s and Y21s SnT ever had, and oh, not to forget, the celebration after achieving the gold medal, are still as fresh as new.

As y‚Äôall would have already there‚Äôs always something happening on campus, if you are active enough. Thus, with the end of Inter-IIT, came soaring high dreams of multiple sophomores to stand in elections, and after initial doubts I was no exception. Giving wings to my dream, in one such Inter-IIT party hosted by Y19s and Y20s of JLR PS, in a totally unconscious state, I said and I quote ‚ÄúArnav, mujhe bhi gensec banna hai‚Äù. This was just a mere start of my seriousness and devotion toward council activities, without the slightest idea how it would become my whole identity. Can‚Äôt thank that one senior enough for motivating me enough to participate.

But everything you desire requires sacrifice, hardwork and difficult decisions to be made, which eventually embarks us on the journey we are meant to be ( or what we think we are meant to be). One such decision, where I had to drop MSO201 after midsems in the most overwhelming 4th semester of EE, with too many doubts in my mind regarding the upcoming intern season, was one of those starting steps to the journey ahead.

With summer came the passion to take up as many things as possible, projects under prof, summer projects mentoring, Summer course, and just to ice this whole cake up, acting general secretary for a month. Of course, my newly ignited council passion wasn‚Äôt going to die anyway soon. During the same time, I was running around the Admin offices, interacting with deans whose positions and their significance were way above my mind, managing SL booking, and came up with the idea of organising SnT‚Äôs first Tech Hackathon. Oh, did I forget to mention the intern prep in which I was lagging with no solid prior background in DSA of any kind? I was under the impression of learning new things every day I loved and which I did, but at the expense of my intern prep. If I could somehow turn back time, I would definitely rethink the duration for which the suffered intern prep could be compensated for.

This summer felt like a storm I had willingly walked into. Between the projects, internship work, internship prep, Council work, mentoring for the summer project, and to top it all off‚Äîa summer course‚ÄîI was stretched beyond limits. There was barely a moment to breathe. Calls with family became infrequent, and my closest friends‚Äîthe people who had meant everything to me in college‚Äîstarted to feel distant. Not because I wanted that, but because I couldn‚Äôt keep up. I thought I could handle it all. Turns out, I was wrong.

The summer passed in a blur, and before I could even process it, the intern season was at the doorstep. Thankfully, by then, I had covered DSA and probability & stats thoroughly. I was somewhat confident. The OPCs, whom I met during my CoCo period, hinted at the shortlisting of the techno-managerial and consulting roles by looking at my profile. Given my past experiences, I genuinely thought I‚Äôd at least land a shortlist in the techno-managerial domain.

But no‚Äînothing. Not a single shortlist, except a random shortlist (yeah, that‚Äôs what various major banks and MnCs do). No shortlists for the roles I had prepared for, not even from the software and banking firms for whom I‚Äôd painstakingly completed every test. One after another, rejections piled up like unanswered questions. It was exactly 10 days after Day 1 that finally two shortlists came my way‚ÄîOracle IndiaandBarclays India. I wasn‚Äôt too keen on the SDE path and was genuinely hopeful about Barclays‚Äîit felt aligned with what I wanted. But fate had its own plans. The Oracle interview was scheduled a day before Barclays. I knew I had one shot. That night, I didn‚Äôt sleep. I packed my bag, skipped breakfast, and walked into the Tutorial Block that morning with nerves and caffeine in equal measure. Dozens of students were already there. I waited patiently, anxiously, as nearly 40 candidates were interviewed before I got my chance.

And then, something just clicked. Maybe it was my survival instinct, or maybe all the pain and pressure just melted into clarity. But in that room, I was at my sharpest.Three rounds‚Äîeach one smoother than the last. I didn‚Äôt fumble. I didn‚Äôt doubt. I simply performed. For the first time in weeks, I felt in control again.

During the intern season, the most disheartening thing for me how my resume pointers‚Äîsomething I had worked so hard on in the summers‚Äîdidn‚Äôt help me score at all. Not once was I asked about it, not even in Oracle. Every round boiled down to dry technical questions. Then came Round 3‚Äîthe manager round at Oracle. This time I expressed myself who I really was. I spoke about my extra-curriculars, my passion for leadership, and desire to pursue a managerial position while taking up the leadership role. The interviewer actuallyseemed impressed. But for god‚Äôs sake was it of no use. They had already picked 12 candidates (the number they promised SPO). I returned to my room crushed, trying to keep it together while my wingies tried to console me.
And then‚Äîding. A mail. Recruited by Oracle India. Wait‚Ä¶ WTF just happened?!
Turns out, two of the initial offers were revoked. They ended up offering the internship to me and one other person. Ta-da, suddenly I was on cloud nine.

Intern season did more than just give me an internship‚Äîit was a reality check. It showed me who genuinely stood by me and who were just around for their own convenience. I drifted away from friends I was once really close with. If only I had stayed grounded, maybe those friendships wouldn‚Äôt have needed repair in the semesters that followed.

Burnout hit me hard over the next 3-4 months. I was emotionally drained, and¬† just wanted to escape‚Äîfrom college, from the toxicity, from everything. I stopped interacting with most of my batchmates, especially the ones from batti. It felt like I was slowly disappearing from the very circle that once felt like home.

I started spending almost all my time at the Electronics Club‚Äîeither brainstorming new initiatives or simply chilling and chatting with mybacchas(secretaries). This was, hands down, the most wholesome position I held in my four years at IITK with no pressure, no burden‚Äîjust pure involvement and joy. I grew so close to all of them that it started feeling like my own separate family where I was their bada bhai, sharing our life pieces, doing random backchodi and of course the club work. Beyond work, the movie nights, Diwali celebrations, and endlessbullasessions kept me hooked on. They gave me something to look forward to. And as a bonus, the club‚Äôs performance and reception on campus improved significantly. Everything felt smooth. Organic. Happy.

Then came Antaragni‚Äîand with it, a sudden surge of political undercurrents around the upcoming General Elections. Until then, I had stayed away from anything even remotely political because a senior once told me,‚ÄúSnT mein politics nahi chalti. That‚Äôs not our culture.‚Äù I held onto that.
But now, out of nowhere, it was like a storm had hit. ‚ÄúBhai‚Äôs 2 Hall me collusion hogya, ab ye ye bhi jaaenge, isko is hall ke hec ka support h, usko is hall.‚Äù

I was just standing there thinking‚ÄîSeriously? This is how it works?People I once believed would make great candidates simply backed out. That‚Äôs when it hit me: politics wasn‚Äôt just creeping in‚Äîit was taking over. Now after seeing everything in 4 years, I can easily affirm this bitter truth: to become an effective leader, you need both‚Äîthe will to work and the political instincts to survive. Lacking any one could bring a lot of instability in any council.

I got serious about my preparation. Reaching out to seniors, trying to understand the landscape better, drawing a map of the people across batches whom I could possibly tap into later (let‚Äôs just say‚Äîthat‚Äôs a story for another day üòÇ).

But due to the emergence of a dummy candidate from my hall and the usual pitiful hall-level political maneuvering, I decided to step back from the General Elections. Instead, I shifted focus to Inter-IIT high prep PS this time and secondly, the Winter Camp, which a few Y21s and I revamped, pushing it into the core team spotlight.

Through a combination of teamwork and a bit of luck, our problem statement earned a gold medal‚Äîmarking my second Tech Meet gold. In that moment, the sense of accomplishment felt especially genuine, and I was quietly glad to have avoided the election whirlwind.

Right after the Inter-IIT contention meet in Madras, a few close seniors asked if I wasreallysure about stepping away and how I might regret it later. I just smiled and replied, ‚ÄúKaam hi toh karna hai, ISec jaaunga‚Ä¶ wahan election ka dekh lena aap sab üòÇ .‚Äù

By then, my mind was already made up. Of course, things took an unexpected turn on January 5th, nomination day for GE‚Äô24. I‚Äôll leave those details for another time‚Äîbut they did change the course of my college journey.

That day, I chose a side. And from there on, I threw myself headfirst into Students‚Äô Gymkhana politics. For the next 20 days, I spent most of my time at Hall 5‚Äôs I-Mid, especially Prakhar bhai ka room, with every plan, every meeting, every idea, a lot new memories and connections were brewed there. Going along with Dhruv & others almost all the time‚Äîcampaigning, strategizing, sitting across hostels with different people. And somewhere in the chaos‚Ä¶ I started to enjoy it.

The same politics I had kept myself away from‚Äîso consciously, even for the sake of my ambitions‚Äîwas now becoming something Igenuinelyenjoyed. It was about the people, bonds, and a sense of purpose.

Within just a week of GE‚Äô24 ending, the nominations for Institute Secretary were out. And even before I could soak in the aftermath of the elections, I had already received asoftNOTA threat and little resistance due to my recent involvements as well as actions.

And then came D-Day. Despite all odds, I got elected‚Äîwith an 18-4 vote from the council. It was the first time I ever presented in front of so many people in my life and realised how important role communication can play.

Over time, I became deeply familiar‚Äîalmost too familiar‚Äîwith the student politics: collusions, dummy candidates, covert recordings, betrayals. Thatnaiveversion of me? Long gone. Instead of being disgusted, I got more drawn in and wanted to be present. Gymkhana wasn‚Äôt just a thing to me anymore‚Äîit felt personal.
All the ambition I thought I had lost urged me more to fulfill my responsibility.

I started working on everything I had proposed and from that, came some of the most impactful external collaborations I‚Äôve ever been a part of.¬† Working withUP Police, cold-reaching out to multiple startups for partnerships in HackIITK, all these efforts meant something and I finally got what I wanted, Networking with Alumni, Startups & great minds outside.
And just when you thought this chapter was all about politics and councils?
Nope.

All the days I spent with Chitresh and Patil (divyansh), they supported me all the time, taking care of me like their own brother (and damn, they are my own brother). How can one forget Hall-3 F block, my room F267, the place I liked most in the entire campus. That room and those roommates will never go out of my memory. All the time spent with them 2 (& my wingies), all the nights we simply stargazed from F block rooftop, is the most valuable thing I have in this academic year of 2023-24.

The 6th semester also gave me something I didn‚Äôt even know I needed‚Äîrekindled friendships. The people I‚Äôd slowly drifted from during intern season found their way back into my life. From a random, spontaneous plan to Ayodhya to watching an IPL match in Lucknow‚Äî(and making Ridin realize how good the place near Ekana Stadium actually is)‚Äîit was wholesome. Full circle.‚Äô
It was a strange, beautiful transition‚Äîfrom being a little innocent guy who hated politics‚Äîto getting knee-deep in the dirt‚Ä¶ and genuinelylikingit.
As for Summer ‚Äô24 and my time in Bangalore? Let‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ skip that chapter.

Fast forward three months‚Äîhere I am, back home after wrapping up my internship at Oracle, waiting anxiously for the PPO result with uncertainty about even accepting it. The thought of balancing placement prep, 65 credits (thanks to the three courses I had dropped earlier), council work, and Inter-IIT responsibilities felt overwhelming. After a lot of back and forth, I decided to accept the PPO‚Äîand with that, shifted my focus completely away from placement.

7th semester, the toughest phase of college ‚Äì academics, career, personal life, and professional commitments‚Äîall came crashing down in waves.I began the semester with Tech Sprint, gearing up for Inter IIT. We aimed to cover almost every domain. It quickly became clear how much we lacked in several areas. Every task I took on felt heavier than it should have, mostly because of my packed schedule. Still, I somehow kept things afloat‚Äîat the cost of my classes (all thanks to Ridin for covering my assignments).Things went relatively smoothly‚Ä¶ until mid-September, when CL nominations arrived. Once again, politics stirred. The same frustrating questions resurfaced: Do egos matter more than service to the college? Where is the line between fairness and favoritism? It was draining.

Amid this, I‚Äôm incredibly grateful to the Gymkhana stakeholders and the friends who stood by me. But the timing couldn‚Äôt have been worse‚Äîthis all blew up right around midsems. Add to that some already ongoing personal struggles, and suddenly the one thing I had been most passionate about became a source of emotional anxiety..The fallout, you ask? My midsems took a hit, and I had to drop my fourth and final course‚ÄîTheory of Computation. And just like that, I missed out on completing one of my minors.

Somehow, after nearly a week of intense discussions, negotiations, and closed-door conversations, things finally got sorted. I was back in it‚Äîthe very thing I had almost thought to walk away from. There was a moment when I was so disgusted, but I got back to the grind to adhere to my sanity.

Next up was attending the first offline Tech Board Meet, representing IIT Kanpur at IIT Bombay. Aligning with the Council Core Team and Tech Sprint mentors, mapping out strategies to tackle all the problem statements, managing the heaps of administrative work, and looking after the entire contingent, everything was smoothly working out.

We practically lived in the Senate Hall and DJAC, nights blended into days. And right there, beside me always, were Mohika and Anunay. This phase was the most emotionally charged part of my college life; everything I had done, everything I had pushed through, culminated here.

An amazing team‚ÄîAnunay, Mohika & me‚Äîworking with insane synergy, but not everything was smooth sailing.As for the results? They didn‚Äôt land in our favor. And honestly, that deserves an entirely separate article. But even then, I walked away with a ton of positives, the dedication from the contingent, especially the current and incoming core teams, was truly unmatched. I still remember the sleepless nights, living on barely 3 hours of sleep, day after day, for like a month and a half. Mornings spent running around the DoSA office, evenings to late nights consumed in Senate Hall/DJAC. It was relentless.But in that chaos, I grew. I became more responsible, more mature, more confident. I learned what it meant to carry a team, not just logistically, but emotionally. Of course, this came at a cost‚Äîmy health took a massive hit. But looking back, I wouldn‚Äôt trade those moments for anything.The time after the Inter-IIT contention meet and the result announcement was the first time in a very long while that I cried. It wasn‚Äôt just disappointment‚Äîit was heartbreak. The countless hours, the sleepless nights, the sheer grind put in by not just the three of us, but by the entire contingent‚Ä¶ it all felt like it vanished in a moment.

In the thick humidity of Bombay, we‚ÄîMohika, Anunay, and I‚Äîstepped off campus. There were tears in our eyes, heaviness in our hearts, and disappointment written all over our faces while inhaling that cigarette, as the wind passed me, so did a wave of realizations, regrets, and what-ifs, that was my personal ‚ÄúKhada hoon aaj bhi wahi‚Äù moment.

Leading this contingent was, without question, the thing I am most proud of in my four years at IITK. And it shattered. It shattered in a way I hadn‚Äôt prepared for. I kept asking myself‚Äîwhere did we go wrong? When we got back to the room, I couldn‚Äôt even gather the strength to face my own team and break the news.

But then‚Äîsomething unexpected happened. I saw the Y22s. The way they carried themselves in that moment‚Äîwith maturity, resilience, and quiet determination‚Äîmoved me. Each PS lead wasn‚Äôt demoralized. In fact, they were more motivated than ever. That night, I addressed the entire contingent before the networking dinner, and what I saw in their eyes, especially from the Y22s and Y23s, was fire.I hope they carry that spirit forward. That culture.And just like that‚Ä¶ enough of SnT. Let‚Äôs rewind to the final year‚Äîto theBakchod Block of Hall 1.Officially, I was allotted B-top. But practically, I lived in B-mid, my pseudo-room B205, with Ishan Saxena, mera bhai jaisa dost. It‚Äôs wild to think I barely knew 5‚Äì6 people in that wing earlier, and yet, by the end of August, we were a full-blown family. We went on wing outings, pulled countless night-outs, and had some legendary sessions (iykyk). Then came Antaragni, followed by Ritviz Pronite. The memories hit hard, especially with the realization that this was the last one together. We enjoyed every second‚Äîso much so, I honestly don‚Äôt even remember Day 4. üòÑBy then, the placement wave had already begun. A quiet panic had taken over the campus. Friends were getting offers left and right, and every acceptance felt surreal, bringing relief and joy. Especially when you‚Äôve already pre-booked your trip with those very friends, who were sitting for placements!And then came the crown jewel of it all. After the Cult Meet, just before New Year, we flew off to Vietnam, my first college trip (too late but too good), and also my first international trip.
It‚Äôs hard to put into words what that trip meant. Maybe some things are best left unwritten. But one thing I know for sure: I‚Äôll carry that journey with me for life.

As the final semester began, our only aim was to make as many memories as possible. From dancing in DE‚Äô25 with my wingies‚Äîsomething I never imagined myself doing‚Äîto participating in Galaxy one last time, I‚Äôll miss going down almost every day, seeing juniors pouring their hearts into practice, planning, and prepping, Whether it was the last fest, those spontaneous chill nights, or just rejoicing with friends one last time, somewhere along the way, I made peace. Peace with a few regrets, a few missed goals, and a few dreams that didn‚Äôt quite land the way I‚Äôd imagined. But in letting go of some of those targets, I ended up discovering parts of myself I never knew existed. I explored things I would have never dared to even think of when I first walked into this campus.

It‚Äôs way too hard to even express in words what all time I spent with all of them, all the talks, a lot of bakchodi, a lot of emotional talk, and tons of memories. I am certainly sure I met the best people and I am grateful for such an experience. Maybe only a gallery could express it a bit but all those uncaptured moments, only residing in our memory is the best takeaway from my college life and this is what I will cherish always.

That shy teenager, filled with doubts and second-guessing every move‚Ä¶ is now leaving as someone who‚Äôs far from perfect, but confident enough‚Äîto make decisions, to face uncertainties, and to embrace the unknown. Of course, there are so many friends, mentors, and juniors who haven‚Äôt been named here‚Äîbut each of them has left an imprint on my journey and I‚Äôll be forever grateful for all that I could from them.

So, how would I rate my college life? Honestly, I don‚Äôt care. Because not everything went according to the plan, I may have missed a few targets, dropped a few balls, or even lost some things I thought were important‚Ä¶ but I grew.I grew into someone who‚Äôs ready to face the real world. Someone who knows how to take a step forward, even in uncertainty. Someone who trusts himself. Someone who has friends who he can rely on.And maybe, that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about. So here‚Äôs to the journey ahead‚Äîwhatever it may hold.The road continues. And this time, I‚Äôm not afraid to walk it.

title: As We Leave #28: A wistful portrait of a hundred million seconds
content: Disclaimer: Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur, is the exclusive owner of the information on this website. In this 28th edition of As We Leave, Sai Praneeth Donthu, a Y21 from the Department of Mathematics and Scientific Computing, looks back at a life shaped by sweltering summers, late-night walks, and the quiet company of a crow outside Hall 9. His journey was never linear ‚Äî more a janky cassette of scattered memories than a clean arc. From pandemic dormancy to chaotic sprints, from cynicism to deep care, from floating through mistakes to finding stillness, each semester added a glitchy, beautiful note.
This AWL is a tribute to misplaced photos, half-spoken goodbyes, and the bittersweet comfort of knowing that not remembering everything doesn‚Äôt mean it didn‚Äôt¬†shape¬†you.

Disclaimer:- The views presented below are the author‚Äôs own and are not in any manner representative of the views of Vox Populi as a body or IIT Kanpur in general. This is an informal account of the author‚Äôs experiences at IITK.

There are ever so many ways to write a memoir of one‚Äôs own youthful escapades into the newly found freedom that college so readily provides. It definitely is a stretch to call my experiences as ‚Äúescapades‚Äù per se, but I might as well give myself the license to lie and exaggerate the grandeur of the life I lived here. Being honest, the only person who would like that version would be my younger pubescent self stuck up in my room in the peak of the pandemic. Of all the ways I could probably go about writing this, I think I‚Äôll choose a more colourful way; it‚Äôll probably be the closest to what my whole as a self went through in my overly imaginative head these past few years. Oh, it‚Äôll be heavily exaggerated and pretentious, so be warned, reader. No Tl;dr‚Äôs üòâ

Four years of history hit me with stunning lucidity the moment I sat to write this, and ironically enough the words to describe them evade me. I‚Äôm done with my run here and I‚Äôll hate the fact that this history will wear down and age as I keep reminiscing and jumping at the same highlights time and again. Where and how do we start from here? Where do we go from here? These questions have been answered by those who came before in their own ways and no doubt I‚Äôll find my own but it fascinates me that such questions are perennial. Maybe that‚Äôs a reason why we have such a thing asAWL‚Äôs‚Äì because we have our own twist on such questions that keep testing each generation and challenges us to search for the perspective that nevertheless defines us. For now though I‚Äôd rather focus on one question ‚Äì How do I start thisAWL?

The first and most prominent thing I will forever remember about the campus is the heat and the summers. I remember the charcoal breath that hit my face as I stepped out of the airplane, the first time I landed in Kanpur. It therefore goes without saying that I hate the summers in this city; I‚Äôm more of a winter guy. And yet as I leave, the last summer feels a tad bit more nostalgic than the long gone winter. While the winters have been more serene and calm with not much to do but hibernate with a nice book in hand, the summers have been chaotic and unruly, bringing out the scintillating colours of everyday life in the campus. I hate the summers in this city, but I‚Äôve grown all the more fond of it for all the colours that light up the campus as soon as the first signs of spring arrive. The variety of flowers I‚Äôve seen are just not found in the city from where I hail from. Countless days of cycling towards classes in a shower of leaves and petals shook from the light wind of spring only cement this memory. If you know me, you know that I love flowers.

I‚Äôve also grown fond of the memories of the many summer nights which only twinkled with the stars above and the light from mischievous eyes embroiled in sophomore college drama. Those nights were filled with gossips underneath streetlights that flickered with the crowding pests. Those nights, we were the nuisance with our dope fuelled ruckus and music that unsettled the creatures of the night whose job it was to never let us sleep. Those were the initial nights that we spent running from campus end to campus end in search of ghosts, rooftops and promises made under an empty sky and an open heart. The absence of light only lets us fill the canvas of night with our own colour, such were those nights, now relics of a bygone era, an era of juvenility. Throughout all the dramas and the-not-so-very-complicated complications that college life later added to my life (which previously as a kid was just mundanity known between four walls and a playground), the only thing I wish to take away and remember is the bittersweet nostalgia held in the faces of close friends and in every green leaf and red brick of the campus.

If you‚Äôre reading this, then you‚Äôre either someone who knows me, someone who is looking back into their pasts or someone who believes that they can see the future by readingAWL‚Äôs. I used to think that although we have the same four years, nothing and everything is nearly the same. Again goes back to what we started with; we all have our own twist to this thing. Makes it all the more beautiful.

On one sweltering April day, perched atop a ledge, I noticed a crow. At a time, where most of the campus wildlife is usually cowering away in their dens and nests from the unforgiving sun, the crow seemed relentless in its posture. What caught my curiosity was the fact that I‚Äôve been noticing the same crow during the same hours of the day for weeks. This episode of college ends for me soon and in one way or another I feel that I can relate to the crow. In this fast-paced and competitive environment that our college unknowingly gives us, with months on end with no respite whatsoever, I often found myself perched upon my own ledge of comfort ‚Äì as I do even now. Unlike the majority of final year students who fight tooth and nail to get any available room in the prestigious rundown that is Hall 1, I preferred the relative peace and comfort of Hall 9. My room faced south, towards Hall 10 and 11, which meant that every evening during sunset, I used to be able to see the huge flock of crows, that the particular road to Mama Mios is known for, flying hither thither and cawing up a storm. It often served as a reminder to take a break for me and at which time I‚Äôd look outside and count all the crows I could until I got bored or fell asleep at my desk.

There was a massive rainstorm the other morning and ever since then I‚Äôve stopped seeing that crow and now whenever I look out my window at sunset, I try, in a flash of senseless stupidity, to catch a glimpse of that crow. Wonder where it is now.

These memories of crows and flowers come from a place of nostalgia. I‚Äôve never questioned the role that nostalgia has played in my life but the weight of it has grown stronger. I‚Äôve started to feel a bit resentful of it ‚Äì It has always treated me unfairly. I guess the colour we give to those black and white days, the way we romanticize them and make way around all our bad decisions and mistakes feels unfaithful to my past self that went through it. The bitterness laced in these feelings isn‚Äôt so subtly hidden.

Under duress of my own conscience, I will have to admit that I‚Äôve become a bitter person. ‚ÄúAll happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way‚Äù is the opener ofAnna KareninabyLeo Tolstoy. I‚Äôve always been aware and kinda obsessed with the life and times ofTolstoyever since as a kid I watched Charlie search for a book named ‚ÄúLeo‚Äôs Toystore‚Äù by ‚ÄúWarren Piece‚Äù (which is whatCharlie mistook for the famousWar And PeacebyLeo Tolstoy) from ‚ÄúThe Peanuts Movie‚Äù which was based on the celebrated comic strip. As a content kid with no more to ask but for the latest hot wheels car or the TV remote, it never struck me as it does to me now. We all suffer in our own pools of self-doubt, misgivings, and consequences to our actions and we all try to jump out. Maybe we need to start by learning to swim. Both literally and figuratively, I‚Äôve only ever managed to float.

I prefer the solace of my own room these days rather than the more crowded areas of the campus. It comes from a place of understanding and whatever little maturity I hope to have gained over the course of the last year. We‚Äôve all been naive when we‚Äôve entered college and seen the sprawling acres of red and green for the first time, bubbling with buoyant excitement and floating to make friends with every last person. And as the years pass, some people do manage to maintain every single relationship despite the dramas, but I for one feel that I‚Äôve been able to see both the best sides of people and also the most horrible ones. No wonder we prefer animals and dogs.

Clearly I‚Äôve changed. I‚Äôm not the old version of me from my first year who was overly cautious and scared, who thought twenty times as if a late night walk in the nighttime heat would over dehydrate me. Do I like the version of me that I‚Äôve become?

I must admit that I‚Äôve very clearly demonstrated that I may have symptoms of ADHD in the way I have gone about writing the AWL but bear with me, I feel that that‚Äôs what college was to me ‚Äì a janky cassette tape with sporadic moments. Nothing was ever linear, time was always wonky, it was as if the bell tower rang at its own pace. On one hand there are some semesters that I can barely remember head or tail, whereas on the other there are others which are etched into my memory. An argument can be made that life in general works in the same way, but I felt that it was more noticeable to me with semesters which are quite short. Either way, forgive me for the horrible AWL I‚Äôve written.

Take for instance my first semester at college, which due to the pandemic was cut short and squeezed into three months of online meets, countless co-op games and ever so little academics. We were fed a falsehood of college life which we knew at the time but all we could do was will the pandemic rates go down so that we could taste the real deal. Those days are vivid, despite the lack of activity beyond the desktop chair, for even though it was online, the essence of first year college life was to some extent felt through all the friends I‚Äôve made back then (and are still cheering each other on at the finish line). I would feel that we had gotten the very best ending to the online semester since we were greeted byRitviz, the very week we had come to campus and in a sudden instant we started to feel what real college felt like.

And just like that ever since the fervor towards this newfound freedom to explore , connect and have fun vanished, the months and then the semesters began to merge into one continuous flow of lectures, exams and everything in between. Each of the following semesters that followed were not marked by the immature things that we did, the fests, the parties and what not, but rather surprisingly the littlest of events, be it in our jangled up routines, the courses that we took, or the friendships we took ever so granted. These moments, locked behind some forgotten gate, live a lonely existence in the thousands of photos we took of ordinary life which do not serve their intended purpose of bringing back memory but rather end up being deleted. Even now, as I scroll through the countless photos that eat away at my drive, I come across a motley of photos that I‚Äôm sure held some stupid meaning that I sorely wish to remember but only end up dumping them. I just hope those moments exist in time somewhere in some dimension far away that I can access and cherish.

Recency bias plays a huge deal in this mismatched and inconsistent set of memories. The semesters toward the backend of college were more happening in general than those in the middle and I‚Äôm sure that I‚Äôm not the only one who feels this way. All this has only made me conclude that we only remember the beginning and the ending of things and that in my opinion is the most unfair thing we can do to something that we claim to cherish as something that is life changing and central to our personality.
Life here has been worth my heart that I can give regardless of all the forgotten memories, for they still have had an effect on me as a whole, now and forevermore.

The counselling service made us take a piece of paper with our ranks written on it and burn it up in our first year. This was supposed to ingrain in us the fact that our ranks ,and metrics decided by some test, do not matter. I guess they need to tell us, the last years‚Äô, to do the same thing but now with our CPI‚Äôs; after all it too is a metric. For all the symbolism and all it‚Äôs worth with its deep meaning or whatever it all feels very shallow when you realise that the same people who serve this gyaan to unsuspecting juniors are the same bunch of people who‚Äôd do anything to get a higher grade.

The definitions of life, achievements and success grew a new dimension the moment I stepped into college. All of a sudden I was not only bad in one thing but now I was bad in a multitude of things. All of a sudden I did not know what I wanted ‚Äì the freedom of the careless moon, or the discipline beneath the watchful sun. People often quote that the‚ÄúJack of all trades is the master of none‚Äùbut nine out of ten people forget that he/she is still‚Äúoftentimes better than the master of one‚Äù.I‚Äôm no sort of enlightened saint, rather a hypocrite myself. I‚Äôve always believed that the rat race is never worth it ‚Äì but at the end of the day I‚Äôve always run behind CPI, placement and all those other things. It‚Äôs a heavy expense that I had to pay for this.

And at what expense? The expense I had to pay for not being genuine to myself in this journey was the foot of failure on my face time and again. All of a sudden life was never about working hard enough and you‚Äôll get it but it now was work hard and true to yourself and you might get it.
Does this mean that I‚Äôve changed? Nope, not at all. I‚Äôm a hypocrite, like the rest of us. At Least I have no regrets.

Being grateful for the life I‚Äôve been giving and the circumstances that led me to this very instance somehow does not feel sufficient to clear the debt that I owe. They say that an IIT is an IIT for its people; now that the campus is getting more and more desolate and the wildlife is being spotted again, it feels less and less like home. I don‚Äôt hate it though, I can re-explore the place one last time, from the sunsets on top of hall 10 to the desolate forestry just beyond the old shop, on my own terms. All I need are the songs attached to the night and the memories I so long to revisit and the shoes of Hermes to flit past the SIS guards to places I‚Äôm not allowed to visit. Like the 7th floor of the residential apartments! Do go there, you‚Äôll find a staircase that starts and leads to nowhere.

Time deceives us and we never realise how much one changes, but photos and videos never do. I too have changed throughout the years. The bangalore accent that I used to be proud of has eroded away to a tongue that speaks a more northern accent. No one back home recognises me anymore; each time I‚Äôve gone back it‚Äôs a whole new person they see stepping into the house. It‚Äôs the people here that‚Äôve been responsible, and they have my thanks. I come from Bangalore, a mixing pot of a city, a city from where I‚Äôve met people from multiple cultures and speak different languages and therefore when I came here, I was under the false impression that I would be comfortable with people here in Kanpur. What I had failed to understand was that the people I had often interacted with are from the same shared background unlike those I was about to meet.

I‚Äôve come across such a plethora of wonderful people and at the same time have come across horrible people. Both have done a great deal of justice to the claim thatan IIT is an IIT for its people. Both have made a portrait of me that I will live only to cherish if not for anything else.

The topic of friends is probably one of the hardest things that I can think about, not because some friends have come and gone or some have left a bad taste or that some have just drifted apart, visible only at the far horizon. Rather it‚Äôs in knowing that there probably was something more you could have done or said, something different. Writing about all of them is only cementing the fact that it‚Äôs all done and dusted and you ought to let go now and let them go on their own paths. Writing about them only freezes them in this particular instant, which only puts more importance to each little word, verb and adjective you use. After all, college is all and only about the friends you make.

What words do I choose then? Giving any words as such grossly simplifies the way I feel towards some people. Do I throw praises, or verses rhyming from the book of a poet, or perhaps take individually name and fame them? This comes from a place of deep emotions, and for this moment I will let them talk about the way I feel for emotions are at the core of what makes us feel. If the campus and life had any colour, then these people gave it the vibrance. Thanks for each and every word and moment that you all felt was a good idea to spend with me.
It‚Äôs going to be hard to leave. That bit is for sure.

I‚Äôve come to the end of my line here, I feel aged and I‚Äôve been told that I‚Äôve crossed over into old age already. I can already feel my knees cracking and my cataract thickening. The longer I stay here, the more my bed feels comfier and my eyes feel foggier. I‚Äôve said all my thank yous and goodbyes, I‚Äôve cried my share of tears, I‚Äôve hugged all the people that matter to me and made peace with all the unfinished dramas and I‚Äôve settled all my emotional and actual dues. What else is left?

In the end it‚Äôs not a teary eyed goodbye to this life here, but rather a melancholic one. Some people would wish to have apensieveto visit all the good times, but I‚Äôd rather not. The reality of things is oftentimes much less enjoyable to reminisce on than what nostalgia gives us and I‚Äôm content with that. I‚Äôm sure to forget all the things that I wish not to, but it is the way it is. I‚Äôm content. We all know how this story ends, but we are so sorely underprepared for when it ends. Here‚Äôs to all the words that went unsaid, here‚Äôs to all the laughter that we never had, here‚Äôs to all the things we never did.
Here‚Äôs also to the full stop to end it all. It‚Äôs a pretty heavy one. Weight of a hundred million seconds.
Sai Praneeth Donthu

title: As We Leave #27: Fitting a Model to College Life
content: Disclaimer: Vox Populi, IIT Kanpur, is the exclusive owner of the information on this website.
